Faunus, the rural power, o'er streams and shades</br>Who gentle reigns, dear loves Lyceus mount,</br>Arcadian; yet oftime the god,</br>For lov'd Lyceus, courts the hills
Of fair Lucretilis, and my soft flock</br>Guards from wet winds and Summer's fiery sun.</br>Free ranging thro' the peaceful grove,—</br>Sweet thyme they cull; and each sweet shrub
That latent lies:  nor Martian wolf, nor snake</br>Green spotted dread.  Perchance adown the vale</br>And o'er yon smooth rock, where high nods</br>Ustica, Faunus oaten pipe
Echoes the past'ral song.  Thus blest of heav'n,</br>My gentle life I lead, and sacred powers</br>Watch over me; belov'd my muse,</br>My humble piety belov'd.
Come then, O mind of beauty, for to thee</br>Our rural wealth, fair flowers, and nectar'd fruits,</br>Lavish shall flow;  whate'er with smile</br>Plenty from her rich horn free pours.
Here 'mid the shades that darken the lone vale,</br>Deep hid from burning suns, thy fingers light</br>In melting sounds the Teian lyre</br>Shall wake, and sing the rival nymphs,
Penelope, and her magic arts,</br>With beauties magic charms, so false and fair.</br>Here Lesbian wines, innoxious, pure,</br>Crowning the board, shall tempt thy taste.
Nor fear lest Bacchus stain his festal rite</br>With wild uproar and quarrel; nor yet dread</br>Lest the hot-blooded Cyrus dare,</br>(By envy stung and mean revenge)
Disturb the genial hour — with ruffian hand</br>Tearing the rosy crown from thy fair locks;</br>Nor sparing e'en th' unconscious robe</br>That floats upon thy graceful form.</br>
